During my time in Legazpi, I frequently visited SM Mall Legazpi as my only refuge during frequent power outages in the area. I often brought my 1-year-old son to Kidzoona to keep him occupied. However, our visits were often limited to the mall's operating hours, usually from opening until 5 or 6 PM, due to these power interruption. As an OFW living abroad, I am accustomed to certain levels of compassion and service extended to us parents carrying young children. When bathrooms are crowded, maintenance personnel in other places sometimes offer us the PWD restroom to accommodate our needs. Unfortunately, this was not the case at SM Mall Legazpi. In this particular instance, I needed to use the women's toilet near Kidzoona to change my baby's diaper. The queue was long, and no one offered to let us go ahead. When I approached the PWD restroom nearby, I was surprised to find it LOCKED! I then sought out a maintenance or janitorial staff member and politely asked if I could use the PWD toilet for my baby. His response was a firm 'no,' and I vividly remember the janitor‚Äîa short man with one blind eye‚Äîlooking at me dismissively. This experience was deeply disappointing and disheartening. As a mother and an OFW, I believe that basic compassion and understanding should be extended to all visitors, especially mothers with young children. It is truly heartbreaking to be met with such indifference and inflexibility. I hope the management will consider training staff to be more humane and accommodating to the needs of all guests.

In this particular instance, I needed to use the women's toilet near Kidzoona to change my baby's diaper. The queue was long, and no one offered to let us go ahead. His response was a firm "no," and I vividly remember the janitor‚Äîa short man with one blind eye‚Äîlooking at me dismissively. This experience was deeply disappointing and disheartening. As a mother and an OFW, I believe that basic compassion and understanding should be extended to all visitors, especially mothers with young children. I hope the management will consider training staff to be more humane and accommodating to the needs of all guests, regardless of circumstances.

During my time in Legazpi, I frequently visited SM Mall Legazpi as my only refuge during frequent power outages in the area. I often brought my 1-year-old son to Kidzoona to keep him occupied. However, our visits were often limited to the mall's operating hours, usually from opening until 5 or 6 PM, due to these power interruptions. As an OFW living abroad, I am accustomed to certain levels of compassion and service extended to us parents carrying young children. When bathrooms are crowded, maintenance personnel in other places sometimes offer us the PWD restroom to accommodate our needs. Unfortunately, this was not the case at SM Mall Legazpi. In this particular instance, I needed to use the women's toilet near Kidzoona to change my baby's diaper. The queue was long, and no one offered to let us go ahead. When I approached the PWD restroom nearby, I was surprised to find it LOCKED!. I then sought out a maintenance or janitorial staff member and politely asked if I could use the PWD toilet for my baby. His response was a firm "no," and I vividly remember the janitor‚Äîa short man with one blind eye‚Äîlooking at me dismissively. This experience was deeply disappointing and disheartening. As a mother and an OFW, I believe that basic compassion and understanding should be extended to all visitors, especially mothers with young children. It is truly heartbreaking to be met with such indifference and inflexibility. I hope the management will consider training staff to be more humane and accommodating to the needs of all guests, regardless of circumstances
